message.body: Only when I switch to zeroid, otherwise it's normal; bold and black when I post.
/me is looking at the source code
@erkan changed it a bit to show zeroverse addresses
Thanks @yilmazerkan@zeroverse.bit (or should I say @yilmazerkan ?)
Changing the topic a little bit. Is there a way to query the "auth_user_name" in our users.json? Currently I use grep but the result is not ideal.
@basxto@zid: > a unicorn is just a horse that is a bit more horny than usually
@basxto@zid: that makes sense
By the way, how are you folks doing?
The new update of zeronet now has a delay between publishing changes in a short amount of time, did that negatively impact this chat?
It's probably for the best
@redacted@zv: Just tried it and it works, but only AFTER I visited the site.
Actually not really. Both ways worked here. Even without downloading/deleting the site.
Tried several different variations, deleting the site between the trials. Here is what I found out:
git clone does not download the index, just the git/ and content.json
Well, that's it.
Might be, but Erkan tried first
Yes
It did work. The index is only downloaded when I visited the site with the browser.
Which is odd, since it is not optionally-signed.
/me coined the term "optionally-signed"
So, to be clear, git clone downloaded the repo but not the index.html, which only downloaded via the browser.
I took the liberty of accesing this repo via two proxies for reliability, hope you don't mind.
@erkan@zid: hahah

@erkan@zid: I managed to replicate your error, I think. Did you use the full address or just the site address? (e.g. http://localhost:43110/1MCfWoCtcbPXYc3rhYhKeSAWVpzAQYyWKS/git/testrepo.git or http://localhost:43110/1MCfWoCtcbPXYc3rhYhKeSAWVpzAQYyWKS)
Using localhost or 127.0.0.1 is irrelevant in this case.
The fatal error thing, how long did it take before it showed up?
Could be related to peers, but that seems unlikely.
@redacted@zv: Can you delete the site and try it? Or someone else reading.
But you have the private key and the site is stored in our computers and the proxies, wouldn't be a problem. But that's ok :)
Problem solved, I guess. Next step: try the same thing but with an optionally-signed git dir. This could be the central idea behind a GitHub-like system here. Minus the GUI, of course.
Someone publishes a project in their blog, signs the files as optional and folks can git clone it.
@teszt@zid: Greetings
I get "index.html download failed" when I go to your site. Please sign and publish again. Should work then.
Your content.json (the version I downloaded) says you last modified it on 2 April. Have you ever signed it since then?
Where did the error show up? When you typed yes in the terminal?
terminal == command prompt
That's weird. Never happened to me.
Now you got your new site address?
It works!
@teszt@zid: If you wanted to change something, do you know the process of sending the changes?
What command did you use to publish?
The newest version always "wins". But it shouldn't affect you. What command did you use and what is the error?
That's it then. You need to use ..\Python\python.exe zeronet.py siteSign 17fyoVFQVvBLWC1fnZHmqPzcD9cc1ThjyG --publish
or ..\Python\python.exe zeronet.py siteSign 17fyoVFQVvBLWC1fnZHmqPzcD9cc1ThjyG and then ..\Python\python.exe zeronet.py sitePublish 17fyoVFQVvBLWC1fnZHmqPzcD9cc1ThjyG
Create creates the site. Sign signs it (think of it as updating your site). Publish sends the "update" to the peers (people with your site).
Makes sense?
The best command to change your site is this: ..\Python\python.exe zeronet.py siteSign 17fyoVFQVvBLWC1fnZHmqPzcD9cc1ThjyG --publish

If you add your private key after your site address (..\Python\python.exe zeronet.py siteSign 17fyoVFQVvBLWC1fnZHmqPzcD9cc1ThjyG PRIVATEKEY --publish) then it's even easier, but that can be less secure, I think.
You don't need a new site. All you need is that command. Even your first site will work with that command. What is the exact error?
Can you paste the error here?
That is not an error. That means it worked.
"Modified. If this message is seen then publish works."
From this site: http://127.0.0.1:43110/17fyoVFQVvBLWC1fnZHmqPzcD9cc1ThjyG
What error is that? Please paste here.
Please try again with the other site (17fyoVFQVvBLWC1fnZHmqPzcD9cc1ThjyG), I have a theory.
Just the sitePublish
Then paste the error
@yilmazerkan@zv: ;)
@redacted@zv on marketplace: do you say that because it would change the focus of the project or something else?
Greetings citizens of the world.
@erkan@zid: why did you label G014 as "bug"?
Hey @redacted@zv and @erkan@zid, sorry for not responding earlier/yesterday. Had to leave.
I just read this(https://www.wired.com/2016/05/craig-wright-privately-proved-hes-bitcoins-creator/) and you guys are already talking about "Satoshi", what a great chatroom.
I'm reading more articles but it does seem weird that Andresen claims to be "convinced beyond a reasonable doubt".
Hello :)
Just read. One moment
That doesn't explain Andresen, though. Would he throw away his reputation for an attempt to make the real Satoshi show up?
https://twitter.com/petertoddbtc/status/727078284345917441
"FYI, @gavinandresen's commit access just got removed - Core team members are concerned that he may have been hacked."
@redacted@zv: Yeah, it appears that Andresen already said in a conference today that he was not hacked. So Todd will probably give him access again.

I honestly don't know what to think. There are so many theories going on. The fact that Wright tried to convince us (poorly at that) means that if he is Satoshi he will, or should, do it properly next.
If he is not, then this is the biggest proof so far.
Mic drop: https://i.imgur.com/zsbU1FU.png
Interesting. But to what end?
Ping
All you folks should see this amazing Linux distro: https://www.qubes-os.org/
